ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: My Greek reading ability and knowledge of Athenian literature improved. I also feel that my knowledge of pedagogy improved.

I became a much better reader of Greek, a quicker, more fluent reader, a reader more attuned to the nuances of translating. I was suddenly in conversation with the history of scholarship on each piece we read through Prof. Greenwood's amazing handouts. And we thought critically about pedagogy the whole time.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was designed and executed well. I cannot think of any weaknesses.

One of the best things about this course was the many ways of assessment it employed, from asking us to take standard translation quizzes to having us present in class and make a lesson plan. The nature of the course is to ask students to make connections across every text we read as we form a picture of Greek literature for ourselves; I think one improvement to the course could be making those connections more explicit throughout the semester, whether that's pausing at specific points to look back or creating a visual map at the very end.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes; it was challenging and enjoyable.
